stream_context.summary: Kaze held a bonus stream to work on a large, western-themed level. He implemented NPCs, showcased new train effects, and addressed a critical out-of-memory error by cutting a planned area ('Yoshi Ranch'). The majority of the stream was dedicated to a lengthy and complex debugging session to fix the behavior of the vanilla Pokey enemy, which had been broken by his custom engine optimizations.

development_findings.summary: A significant RAM limitation was hit, forcing Kaze to cut an entire planned area ('Yoshi Ranch') from the western-themed level to ensure it could load and run properly.
development_findings.quote: We're definitely gonna have to cut to Yoshi Ranch, which is sad, but it is what it is.

development_findings.summary: A lengthy debugging session for the Pokey enemy revealed a conflict between vanilla game logic and Kaze's custom engine optimizations, requiring a specific code modification to fix.
development_findings.quote: My engine made it so that if an object doesn't move it doesn't Raycast the floor every tick. But they needed the floor to be Raycasted every tick. So I just removed that requirement basically.

development_findings.summary: The team uses narrative tricks, like having NPCs say shops are sold out, as a clever way to build atmosphere while conserving memory by not having to model and load extra assets.
development_findings.quote: This is a trick we do so we don't actually have to 3D model the stuff here because we are getting pretty close to running out of RAM.

development_findings.summary: A custom algorithm for generating random object rotations has the unique side effect of making every rotation distinct, which could be used to detect speedrun cheaters using a different RNG table.
development_findings.quote: In this game, every rotation is unique, because we actually use a signed approximation algorithm instead of a rounded lot. So actually, you could catch a cheater pretty easily in this game.

development_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a strong, contrarian design philosophy, stating his dislike for entire genres (2D platformers) and common mechanics (boss fights), which heavily influences his own creative choices.
development_findings.quote: I don't like 2D platformers... I don't like boss fights in video games... You guys need to realize I hate games.

development_findings.summary: Kaze showed off new visual and sound effects for the level's trains, including camera shake, to make them feel more impactful and dangerous as obstacles.
Kaze suspects that a weird hitbox issue with the Pokey is not specific to that enemy but is a more general bug in the engine affecting how objects are interacted with.
development_findings.quote: I think the shadow is just an unrelated bug that's like a general object thing and not a pokie thing.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a personal philosophy favoring concise and precise language over metaphorical idioms, which he views as 'noise'.
context_findings.quote: I think idioms are really dumb. I don't like them because like why are people making idioms like just say the words you want to say bro.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is experiencing significant financial disruption due to long-standing issues with PayPal, which has frozen his account and is causing donations to be sent to an old, inaccessible email address.
context_findings.quote: They asked me to verify my identity three months ago and I did and they said it will take two days and they still haven't verified it and now they just closed my account basically.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a cynical view of ROM hacking competitions, believing they reward 'playing to the audience' and criticizing recent deadline extensions as unfair to participants who adhered to the original schedule.
context_findings.quote: I think it's a little shady because you are committing to a four-week project, but then the deadline extends by two weeks. Now your choice is like, okay, either I put in an additional two weeks of work to try and get a better placement, or I accept that I submitted a four-week project to a six-week competition.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is conscious of his professional position at Gears for Breakfast and makes an effort to separate his personal opinions on stream from his employer's official stance.
context_findings.quote: I just felt the need to say that because I don't want to get the company in trouble over me saying some dumb shit.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is taking a week off from his job at Gears for Breakfast and chose to do a 'bonus stream', indicating a strong personal drive to work on the project in his free time.

biobak.summary: Kaze jokingly blames Biobak for a texture on a bandit model that was not receiving lighting correctly, indicating Biobak's role in creating character assets.
biobak.quote: Why, Biobak? Why? Why would you do this to us?

badub.summary: Kaze praises Badub's music for creatively using the original Mario 64 sound font to produce a soundtrack that feels entirely new yet retains a similar, desired vibe.
badub.quote: It's freaking amazing like how different from the default Mario 64 sound. Most of it is still the default Mario 64 sound font... but they're used in really creative ways.

zeina.summary: Kaze assigns asset creation tasks to Zeina during the stream, specifically requesting a 'tumbleweed store' asset and animations for a new Pokey enemy.
zeina.quote: I gotta ask Zeina to make a tumbleweed store here.

zeina.summary: Zeina appeared in chat near the end of the stream to ask Kaze about his recent work on the game's shadow system.

key_stories.title: The RAM Crisis and the Yoshi Ranch Cut
key_stories.summary: Faced with a hard RAM limit that crashed the game, Kaze made the pragmatic decision to cut an entire planned section of the level, the 'Yoshi Ranch'. This story demonstrates the technical constraints of the N64 and Kaze's willingness to sacrifice content for stability.
key_stories.challenge: The western-themed level became too complex, exceeding the N64's RAM limits and causing the game to crash upon loading.
key_stories.process: After confirming the crash was due to memory constraints, Kaze identified the 'Yoshi Ranch' section as the most viable part to remove. He then deleted its assets and walled off the entrance to solve the problem.
key_stories.outcome: By cutting the 'Yoshi Ranch' area, enough memory was freed to make the level stable. Kaze accepted the loss of content as a necessary compromise for performance, calling the cut area 'unnecessary fluff anyway'.
key_stories.key_quote: We are out of memory. Cool, cool, cool. I mean, that makes sense. This level is 40,000 triangles.

key_stories.title: Debugging the Broken Pokey
key_stories.summary: A custom engine optimization, designed for performance, inadvertently broke a standard enemy from the original game. Through meticulous debugging, Kaze identified this complex interaction and implemented a targeted fix, showcasing the challenges of modifying a game's foundational code.
key_stories.challenge: The standard Pokey enemy from the original Mario 64 was completely broken in the new engine. Its body parts would either disappear or fly high into the air, making it unusable.
key_stories.process: Kaze undertook a lengthy debugging process, methodically disabling parts of the enemy's code. He discovered that his engine's optimization—which stops non-moving objects from checking for a floor every frame—was the cause. The Pokey's segments, moved by a parent script, were considered 'non-moving' and thus lost their ground reference.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully debugged and fixed the Pokey by creating an exception to his optimization, restoring its original behavior. He celebrated by placing the newly functional enemy throughout the level.
key_stories.key_quote: My engine made it so that if an object doesn't move it doesn't Raycast the floor every tick. But they needed the floor to be Raycasted every tick. So I just removed that requirement basically.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions needing assets from Zeina (animations, models) and Badub (music) and reacts to a texture from Biobak. The actual process of how these assets are requested, iterated on, and integrated is not explained.
questions: What is the typical workflow for requesting and receiving assets like models, music, or animations from the team?
How do you provide feedback or request revisions from the artists and composer?
Is there a formal task management system, or is collaboration handled more informally through chat?

open_questions.context: Kaze notes that managing memory 'per area' is much harder in the decompilation project than it was with older ROM hacking tools, leading to the decision to cut the Yoshi Ranch.
questions: What are the biggest technical trade-offs you've faced using the decompilation project compared to traditional ROM hacking?
Besides memory management, what other unexpected challenges or limitations has the decomp project introduced?
Conversely, what key features or freedoms has working in C with the decomp project given you that would have been impossible before?

open_questions.context: When asked about the legality of using Nintendo's code, Kaze deflects, calling it a 'ship of Theseus' problem and stating he's 'not a lawyer'. He also expresses concern about not getting his employer in trouble.
questions: Has your perspective on the potential legal risks from Nintendo changed over your many years in the hacking community?
How do you navigate the boundary between your professional work and your personal passion projects that exist in a legal gray area?
Where do you personally draw the line on what feels like 'your' creation versus Nintendo's original work?

open_questions.topic: Creative and Personal Dynamic with Zeina
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions his spouse, Zeina, in a professional context, assigning her tasks for animations and models. Their dynamic as both collaborators and partners is clear but unexplored.
questions: How does your creative process with Zeina work? Do you provide strict direction, or is it a more fluid, collaborative exchange of ideas?
How does being married impact your professional collaboration on a demanding creative project?
Does Zeina's influence extend beyond specific asset requests into the broader design or feel of the game?
